--- Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrote:
> > We also use XML to persist information about runs,
> and
> > we use XSL style sheets to convert the XML into
> SVG
> > for display purposes.
> 
> This is really clever. 

Thanks. :)

> This could easily be extended
> to other forms of
> data rendering too... and its pretty much
> implementation-agnostic isn't
> it? As long as you have a decent XML library.

Yes...that's the idea.  If we can all get on the same
page, we'd easily be able to share XML data, load each
other's populations into our implementations, etc.
 
> Are the XSL style sheets included with your
> distribution? 

Yes.  Right now we've got five different types of
style sheets:

--One that converts chromosome XML into a spiral
layout of the network
--One that converts network XML into a traditional
layer-based layout of the network
--One that generates a fitness graph from run XML
--One that generates the # of species in each
generation throughout a run, from run XML
--A couple that generate the board, pieces, and move
numbers for Tic-Tac-Toe and Gomoku

These are all part of the distribution.  And in the
run.xml, we've embedded a reference to the fitness
graph XSL style sheet, so that if you open run.xml in
your browser during a run, it dynamically refreshes
the browser and redraws the SVG output every few
seconds, so you can see the fitness progress of the
run.

And speaking of our distribution, we've registered on
SourceForge, and we trying to finally get it uploaded
to our CVS repository there.  We'll have a website to
link to soon as well.  But anyone who's interested in
taking a look at the rough code, just e-mail me or
Philip and we'll be happy to send it your way. 

> I started out using XML to represent the all of the
> data from a single
> run, but it turned out to be really bulky. I didn't
> even consider piping
> that information directly into SVG though...

Well, we still would like to be able to persist every
chromosome from every run...and yeah, that gets very
bulky very quick.  We looked at some opensource native
XML databases, but haven't really bothered with it
lately.  We'll probably end up using a SQL database,
though.

Derek
